title: 110_s2474
content: The Emergency Port of Entry Personnel and Infrastructure Funding Act of 2007, also known as the Act, defines key terms such as "Northern border" and "Southern border" in relation to the United States. It includes provisions for customs and border protection personnel at ports of entry. United States Customs and Border Protection will hire additional staff during fiscal years 2009 through 2012, including 2,000 full-time officers for land ports of entry on the Northern and Southern borders, 1,000 officers for air and sea ports, 600 supervisory officers, and 200 support staff. Additionally, there will be staff enhancements specifically for Texas. During fiscal years 2009 through 2012, United States Customs and Border Protection will hire 750 full-time officers for land ports of entry in Texas and 500 full-time officers for air and sea ports of entry in Texas. The Secretary of Homeland Security may waive limitations on personnel to meet these requirements. All officers will be equipped with secure communication and equipment. Customs and Border Protection officers are equipped with secure communication devices for effective communication. The Secretary of Homeland Security ensures retention incentives, training, and salaries for officers, including 30 hours of immigration law training for new hires at the Federal Law Enforcement Center. Customs and Border Protection officers receive training in immigration and nationality law, language proficiency, use of force, ethics, and substance abuse. Existing officers also undergo annual law enforcement training as prescribed by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Customs and Border Protection officers undergo refresher training on immigration law, use of force standards, and ethics. The Secretary may pay recruitment incentives of $5,000 to $10,000 to retain qualified Customs and Border Protection officers and border patrol agents. Incentive payments are given after 6 months of service, and retention incentives are paid at the end of the fiscal year. The Secretary may provide recruitment incentives to qualified employees selected for payment based on various criteria such as longevity of service, comparative salaries, and costs for replacement and training. The employee must sign an agreement to remain in Federal service. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 allows for increased salaries for Customs and Border Protection employees who have completed at least 1 year of service. Employees must commit to 3 years of Federal service and may face reimbursement if they fail to complete the required time due to separation from service. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 allows for increased salaries for Customs and Border Protection employees based on their years of service. The salary adjustments are specified for different positions within the General Schedule, ranging from GS-5 to GS-14. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act of 2002 allows for increased salaries for Customs and Border Protection employees at GS-5, GS-6, or GS-7 levels. SEC. 4. PORTS OF ENTRY INFRASTRUCTURE. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to construct new ports of entry along the Northern and Southern borders, consult with various stakeholders to determine their locations, and expand Texas ports of entry, such as Eagle Pass. The Secretary will expand inspection lanes at Eagle Pass and Laredo ports of entry in Texas by 6 additional lanes each by the end of fiscal year 2012. SEC. 5. EXEMPTION FROM THE ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES ACT AND THE PAPERWORK REDUCTION ACT. The Administrative Procedures Act and the Paperwork Reduction Act do not apply to actions implementing this Act or its amendments if compliance would impede expeditious implementation, as determined by specified government officials. Government officials such as the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, or the Secretary of Labor can determine that compliance with certain requirements may hinder the quick implementation of the Act or its amendments. SEC. 6. EXEMPTION FROM GOVERNMENT CONTRACTING AND HIRING RULES. In implementing this Act, competition requirements and government contracting rules do not apply. Executive agencies can use noncompetitive procedures, the Secretary of Homeland Security can enter contracts in advance of receiving fees, fees collected must only cover program costs, and the Secretary can appoint employees on a term. The Secretary of Homeland Security can appoint employees on a term, temporary limited, or part-time basis without restrictions on the number or ratio of employees. Department of Homeland Security management officials have the authority to hire employees on a temporary limited or part-time basis. The determination of an executive agency under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act is not subject to challenge by protest to the Government Accountability Office. The executive agency can appoint employees on a term, temporary limited, or part-time basis without restrictions. Challenges to agency determinations under the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act can be made to the Government Accountability Office or the Court of Federal Claims. The agency must report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees and provide quarterly reports on obligations incurred. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to acquire leasehold interests in real property for construction or modification of facilities if necessary for implementing the Act. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 include funds for various sections of the Act, such as $10,000,000 for section 3(d) and $30,000,000 for section 3(e)(1). Additionally, $400,000,000 is allocated for fiscal years 2008 through 2010 to carry out section 4. Authorized appropriations of $100,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2012 for the Secure Border Initiative, Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, US-VISIT program, and Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism.
